data.text: As an endurance athlete of many years. Now ex. But taught and trained by others yes you need salt replacement on big hot days. Normal days not necessarily. Depends upon intensity, climate, and food stops. But balanced. A higher rato of potassium and magnesium is also important. Just salt will throw the system out. And not excessive. One of the anti dehydration products is good. But that also balanced. For most of us not crossing deserts a liter a day of a dehydration product is plenty. Obviously offset with plenty of water and normal food. An extreme day perhaps two. One in morning and one late. An extreme day being the exception. I've been in conditions where I drank up to 9 liters in a day in 12 hours temperatures up to 35-38C and even then that rule of thumb worked fine.
data.author: Daniel Ellsworth

data.text: If you're going through water quickly, it needs to have added electrolytes because in sweating out that much water you're sweating out the sodium, potassium, etc that you get from your diet. If it's cool enough that you're going through water slowly, then you probably don't need to add anything to it. Of course this assumes that you're drinking the water you need. In really hot temperatures sugar is helpful too, both because it facilitates better takeup, and because it's a way to get fuel when you might not feel like ordinary food - for the mid-day hours of a summer ride I'm typically drinking gatorade mix with additional electrolytes added to it, chased by a mouthful of water from a different bottle to get the sugar out of my mouth.

data.text: I have practiced this, yes. 10 years ago, in my early 50s. Besides bicycling upwards of 5,000 miles per year, I took a physical job. Farmhand on a living history farm, set in 1885. The work was brutally physical. Plowing with horses, feeding animals, milking cows, sheering sheep. Lots of other hard labor. And 2013 happened to be very hot. I started waking in middle of the night, unable to move my legs. Muscle cramps. Pickle brine or Gatorade could resolve it in the night. But proactively adding salt to diet prevented the cramps. . Where did I get the idea? From guys shoveling coal into a steam locomotive in the same heat. Among those of us with very physical jobs in high heat, salt was wonderful.

data.text: I've had one other bad experience with somebody *not* getting enough salt. Grand Canyon private non-commercial raft trip in December 2012. I was 1 of 2 boatmen. Other guide rather heavy, and didn't like getting in & out of drysuit to pee in the cold. So he cut back on drinks / electrolytes. We awoke on morning of Day 10, and believed he was dying. Symptoms were right for a heart attack. NPS concurred by sat-phone, and helicoptered him out. Days later, via land-line at Phantom Ranch, we found out he was alive. Saline solution was his cure.
